Stories
Tetsuya “Ted” Fujita
Tetsuya “Ted” Fujita (1920–1998) was a meteorologist who
focused on tornadoes. His work shaped current scientific
understanding of severe weather, including tornadoes,
typhoons, and thunderstorms. That greater understanding
helps keep people safe.
Ted studied mechanical engineering in
college. He became a professor of physics
and also helped make weather maps. He
analyzed typhoons and earned a doctorate.
In 1947, Ted hiked to a weather observation
station at the top of a mountain to gather
data about an approaching thunderstorm.
Ted Fujita was born
in 1920 in Japan. As
a young person, Ted
was fascinated by
the natural world.
Young Ted often dug for clams on the beach at low
tide. He became interested in astronomy when he
learned the position of the moon affects the ocean.
©Curriculum Associates, LLC Copying is not permitted.UNIT 1 STEM Stories2ST
Math Practice 7 Connection
Ted spent years gathering data about tornadoes and looking for patterns and structure.
He used the structure and patterns he found in the data to develop the Fujita scale.

Ted focused on tornadoes for nearly his entire life. What is
something you focus on a lot?
pages.text_preview: Ted focused on tornadoes for nearly his entire life. What is something you focus on a lot?

pages.text_content:
Ted looked for patterns and structure in his work. How do you
use patterns and structure?
Reflection
Questions
Ted wrote a paper about that storm.
A meteorologist in the U.S. read the
paper and invited Ted to come work at
the University of Chicago. Ted moved
to the U.S. with his family.
In 1957 a tornado struck Fargo, North Dakota. Ted
collected and carefully studied nearly 200
photographs to better understand the tornado.
Ted was so focused on tornadoes that people
called him “Mr. Tornado.” After studying them
for nearly 30 years, Ted finally saw a tornado
in 1982! Because of his focus, we know a lot
about tornadoes and how to keep people safe
during storms.
With help from others, Ted studied many
tornado sites. Ted and his wife, Sumiko, used
what they learned to create the Fujita scale
in 1971. This scale describes the strength of
tornados and is still used today.

Find the Area of a Parallelogram
LESSON
pages.text_preview: Find the Area of a Parallelogram LESSON

pages.text_content:
Dear Family,
In earlier grades, your student learned that a rectangle is a type of parallelogram.
One way to find the area of a rectangle is to multiply the length (base) and width
(height) of the rectangle.
To find the area of a parallelogram, you can decompose, or break apart, the
parallelogram and compose the parts into a rectangle.
basebase

Area 5 base 3 height
The base and height of a parallelogram are always perpendicular, forming right
angles. The height can be measured inside or outside the parallelogram.
Your student will be learning how to solve problems like the one below.
What is the area of the parallelogram?
➤
ONE WAY to find the area is to rearrange the parallelogram into a rectangle.
A 5 < • w
5 2.25 • 2
5 4.5
➤
ANOTHER WAY is to use the formula for the area of a parallelogram.
A 5 b • h
5 2.25 • 2
5 4.5
Using either method, the area is 4.5 ft

Look Ahead The words length and width are often used to describe the
dimensions of a rectangle. When describing the dimensions of a parallelogram,
you use base and height.
Any side of a parallelogram can be called the base. You can draw a corresponding
height inside or outside the parallelogram. The base and height are perpendicular.

Dear Family,
This week your student is learning about nets and finding the surface area of
three-dimensional figures. Surface area is the combined area of all the faces,
or sides, of a three-dimensional figure.
Imagine cutting a three-dimensional figure along some of its edges and unfolding
it. The flat, unfolded figure is called a net. You can use the net to find the surface
area of the three-dimensional figure.
Your student will be learning to solve problems like the one below.
What is the surface area of the right
rectangular prism?
➤
ONE WAY to find the surface area is to make a net.
You can find the area of each rectangular face. Then find the sum of the areas.

Dear Family,
This week your student is learning to write and evaluate algebraic expressions.
An algebraic expression is like a numerical expression, except that it contains
variables. A variable is a letter that represents an unknown quantity. Variables are
useful for representing real-world situations such as the one below.
When you go bowling, each game costs $5 and it costs $3 to rent shoes. The total
cost to play x games can be represented with the algebraic expression 5x 1 3.
5x

Your student will be learning how to solve problems like the one below.
At a certain theater, movie tickets cost $9 each. There is a $4 fee to buy
tickets online. The expression 9x 1 4 represents the total cost, in dollars,
to buy x tickets online. What is the total cost to buy 3 tickets online?
➤
ONE WAY to find the cost is to use a table.
1 ticket 1 fee2 tickets 1 fee3 tickets 1 fee
$9 1 $4 5 $13$9 1 $9 1 $4 5 $22$9 1 $9 1 $9 1 $4 5 $31
➤
ANOTHER WAY is to evaluate the expression by substituting 3 for x.
9x 1 4 5 9(3) 1 4
5 27 1 4
5 31
Using either method, the total cost is $31.

pages.text_content:
Write and Evaluate Expressions with Exponents
Dear Family,
This week your student is learning how to evaluate expressions with exponents.
Exponents are used to represent repeated multiplication. One way to show this is
with a power. The base is the number you are multiplying. The exponent is the
number of times the base is a factor.

pages.text_content:
Find Greatest Common Factor and Least Common Multiple
Dear Family,
This week your student is learning about the greatest common factor and the least
common multiple of two whole numbers.
The greatest common factor (GCF) of two numbers is the greatest factor the two
numbers have in common. For example, the GCF of 12 and 18 is 6.
Factors of 12:  1,  2,  3,  4,  6,  12
Factors of 18:  1,  2,  3,  6,  9,  18
The least common multiple (LCM) of two numbers is the least multiple that the
two numbers share. For example, the LCM of 12 and 18 is 36.
Multiples of 12:  12,  24,  36,  48,  . . .
Multiples of 18:  18,  36,  54,  . . .
Your student will be learning to use the greatest common factor to solve problems
like the one below.
A teacher gives out 30 markers and 40 colored pencils. He gives an equal
number of markers and an equal number of colored pencils to each
student. What is the greatest number of students the teacher can give
markers and colored pencils to?
➤
ONE WAY to find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers is to list all
the factors of each number.
Factors of 30:  1,  2,  3,  5,  6,  10,  15,  30
Factors of 40:  1,  2,  4,  5,  8,  10,  20, 40
The common factors of 30 and 40 are 1, 2, 5, and 10. The greatest common
factor is 10.
➤
ANOTHER WAY is to write each number as a product of prime factors.
Then multiply the common prime factors.
30     5 3 • 2 • 5                  40                  5 2 • 2 • 2 • 5
Greatest common factor: 2 • 5 5 10
Using either method, the greatest number of students the
teacher can give an equal number of markers and an equal
number of colored pencils to is 10.
Use the next page to start a
conversation about factors.

because it divides both 12 and 18 without a remainder. You can use common

number of standard cards to each friend.

give trading cards to? Explain how you know.
d.  How is your answer to problem 2c related to factors of the numbers 6 and 15?

143ST
Isabella Aiona Abbott
Isabella Aiona Abbott (1919–2010) was a scientist who
studied ocean plants. As a professor at Stanford University
and the University of Hawai’i, Isabella made connections
between science and cultural traditions.
Isabella Aiona Abbott was born in Hawai’i. Isabella’s
mother practiced many Hawaiian traditions. She
passed along these traditions to Isabella.
An important tradition was cooking
with seaweed, called limu. As a child,
Isabella helped her mother collect limu.
Isabella’s childhood experiences made her love
plants. Isabella earned a Ph.D. and became an
expert in water plants called algae. In 1972, she
became the first woman and the first person of
color to become a biology professor at
Stanford University.
As a scientist and professor, Isabella
remained connected to her Hawaiian roots.
She wrote many books, including a cookbook
with recipes that use seaweed as the main
ingredient. She even made a seaweed cake!
©Curriculum Associates, LLC Copying is not permitted.UNIT 2 STEM Stories144ST
Math Practice 6 Connection
Isabella had to be precise, or careful, when she was studying seaweed. She also made
precise measurements when she used seaweed in recipes. Precise measurements were
important when Hawaiians used seaweed to make medicine.

Reflection
Questions
In 1982, Isabella became a
professor at the University of
Hawai’i. She studied traditional
knowledge and customs about
plants. This is called ethnobotany.
Isabella discovered over 200 types of algae.
Many of these were named after her.
Isabella wanted people to know how important
plants were in Hawaiian culture. She wrote
books explaining how early Hawaiians used
plants to develop medicine and make things
including canoes and clothes.
People called Isabella “The First Lady of
Limu.” She even got to name a research ship
used by other scientists to study marine
ecosystems in Hawai’i. She called the ship
The Hi’ialakia, which means “searching the
pathways of the sea.”
Plants were used in
many ways in medicine
and religion.
